SubTopics: Develop and apply number theory concepts to compare quantities and magnitudes of fractions and whole numbers.
Content: Devon rode his bike a total of 4 miles.
When he stopped for lunch, he had ridden his bike 2 miles.
Which number shows the fraction of the bike ride Devon had completed when he stopped for lunch?

Key.Rationale: This choice uses the number of miles biked.
This choice uses the partial distance (2 miles) as the numerator and the whole distance (4 miles) as the denominator.
This choice uses the reciprocal.
This choice uses an incorrect numerator.

SubTopics: Demonstrate that when a whole or set is partitioned into y equal parts, the fraction 1/y represents 1 part of the whole and/or the fraction x/y represents x equal parts of the whole (limit denominators to 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8; limit numerators to whole numbers less than the denominator; and no simplification necessary).
Recognize and generate simple equivalent fractions (limit the denominators to 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8 and limit numerators to whole numbers less than the denominator).
Compare two fractions with the same denominator (limit denominators to 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8), using the symbols >, =, or <, and/or justify the conclusions.
Content: Susan and Tamara each make a pizza.
Their pizzas are the same size.
Susan cuts her pizza into 3 equal slices.
Tamara cuts her pizza into 6 equal slices.
Which pair of sentences correctly describes whose slices of pizza are bigger?

A.Choice:
Susan's slices are bigger.
Each slice is 2/6 of the pizza.

Key.Rationale: This choice either recognizes that a pizza cut into 3 pieces would have larger pieces than a same-size pizza cut into 6 pieces and converts 1/3 to 2/6 by multiplying the numerator and the denominator by 2 OR converts 1/3 to 2/6 by multiplying the numerator and the denominator by 2 and recognizes that 2/6 is greater than 1/6 by comparing the numerators.

B.Choice:
Susan's slices are bigger.
Each slice is 4/6 of the pizza.

Key.Rationale: This choice adds 3 to the numerator and denominator to change 1/3 to 4/6.

C.Choice:
Tamara's slices are bigger.
Each slice is 1/6 of the pizza.

Key.Rationale: This choice gets the right fraction but does not compare correctly.

D.Choice:
Tamara's slices are bigger.
Each slice is 1/3 of the pizza.

Key.Rationale: This choice gets the wrong fraction and wrong comparison.

SubTopics: Represent fractions on a number line (limit denominators to 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8; limit numerators to whole numbers less than the denominator; and no simplification necessary).
Content: A fraction is represented on the number line shown below.
problems/PA23G3M/media/3a.jpg
Which fraction is represented on the number line?

Key.Rationale: This choice identifies that the number line is divided into 8 equal parts and that the point is on the 6th tick mark (of 8) after 0, so this point represents 6/8.
This choice counts the tick mark at 0 as a part.
This choice switches the numerator and denominator.
This choice uses the two tick marks that are not part of the numerator as the denominator.

SubTopics: Understand various meanings of multiplication and division.
Content: The group of circles below represents the expression 2 Ã— 5.
problems/PA23G3M/media/4a.jpg
Which expression can the group of circles also represent?

Key.Rationale: This choice adds the number of columns to the number of rows.
This choice either selects the related division expression for the given multiplication expression represented by the group of circles OR recognizes that the 10 circles can be divided into 2 rows.
This choice thinks the operation should be changed when switching the order of the numbers.
This choice selects the wrong operation.

SubTopics: Interpret and/or describe whole-number quotients of whole numbers (limit dividends through 50 and limit divisors and quotients through 10).
Content: Colby is making a comic book.
He draws 48 pictures for his comic book.
There are 6 pictures on each page.
How many pages are in Colby's comic book?

Key.Rationale: This choice confuses the products of 6 Ã— 8 and 6 Ã— 6.
This choice confuses the products of 6 Ã— 8 and 6 Ã— 7.
This choice divides 48 by 6 and determines the quotient is 8.
This choice either uses 6 Ã— 10 â€“ 6 Ã— 2 to get 48 but then adds 10 and 2 rather than subtracting 2 from 10 OR identifies an incorrect factor of 48.

SubTopics: Determine the unknown whole number in a multiplication (up to and including 10 Ã— 10) or division (limit dividends through 50 and limit divisors and quotients through 10) equation relating three whole numbers.
Content: Maddison makes beaded bracelets.
She uses 9 beads for each bracelet.
Maddison uses the equation below to find the number of bracelets (â–¡) she can make with 72 beads.
How many bracelets can Maddison make with 72 beads?

Key.Rationale: This choice recognizes that 9 Ã— 8 = 72.
This choice confuses the products of 9 Ã— 8 and 9 Ã— 9.
This choice subtracts 9 from 72 (i.e., uses 9 + 63 = 72).
This choice attempts to find a related fact but uses addition rather than division (i.e., adds 9 and 72).

SubTopics: Interpret and/or model division as a multiplication equation with an unknown factor.
Content: Bruce has 8 baskets and 56 apples.
He wants to put an equal number of apples into each basket.
Which number sentence shows a way Bruce could find the number of apples in each basket?

Key.Rationale: This choice confuses division and subtraction.
This choice understands this as a division problem but confuses the relation between the numbers.

This choice recognizes that 56 Ã· 8 represents the situation and understands that a division problem can be represented as a related multiplication equation, using the number of baskets (8) and the unknown quantity as the numbers to be multiplied and the total number of apples (56) as the product.
This choice understands that division is related to multiplication but confuses the relation between the numbers.

SubTopics: Use operations, patterns, and estimation strategies to solve problems (may include word problems).
Content: Which method describes a way to find the value of 6 Ã— 9?

Key.Rationale: This choice thinks 1 + 8 = 9.
This choice thinks 1 + 5 = 6.
This choice thinks subtracting 1 from 6 Ã— 10 is the same as 6 Ã— 9 since 10 â€“ 1 = 9.

This choice either recognizes that 10 groups of 6, represented by (6 Ã— 10), can be changed into 9 groups of 6, represented by (6 Ã— 9), by removing 6 OR recognizes that 10 â€“ 1 = 9, and therefore 9 groups of 6 can be represented by (6 Ã— 10) â€“ (6 Ã— 1).

SubTopics: Identify arithmetic patterns (including patterns in the addition table or multiplication table) and/or explain them using properties of operations.
Content: Malcolm learned to spell 8 new words during the first week of school.
The table below shows the total number of new words he has learned to spell by the end of each week.
problems/PA23G3M/media/9a.jpg
The total number of new words Malcolm learns to spell makes a pattern.
How many new words had Malcolm learned to spell by the end of week 5?

Key.Rationale: This choice recognizes that the numbers in the pattern are all even, so selects the next even number after 26.
This choice either selects a multiple of 10 between 26 and 38 OR subtracts the week 1 words (8) from the week 6 words (38).
This choice recognizes that the rule for the pattern is â€œadd 6,â€ so adds 6 to the previous number of words (26) and determines the sum is 32.
This choice adds the week 1 words (8) to the week 4 words (26).

SubTopics: Analyze characteristics of polygons.
Content: Which statement about polygons is true?

Key.Rationale: This choice does not understand that the sides of a polygon must be straight.
This choice identifies the definition of a quadrilateral.

C.Choice: All polygons have at least 3 sides.

Key.Rationale: This choice recognizes that polygons have straight sides, 3 or more sides, and that the sides may have different lengths.

D.Choice: The sides are always the same length.

Key.Rationale: This choice considers only regular polygons.

SubTopics: Partition shapes into parts with equal areas. Express the area of each part as a unit fraction of the whole.
Content: Jackie will cut a piece of paper into equal-sized parts to share with three of her friends.
Which shape shows how Jackie could cut the paper so that she and her three friends can each have 1/4 of the paper?

Key.Rationale: This choice identifies a shape that is divided into 4 equal-sized pieces.
This choice identifies a shape that is divided into 4 pieces but does not consider that the pieces are not all equal-sized.
This choice identifies a shape that is divided into 5 equal-sized pieces made from 4 equal-spaced â€œcutsâ€.
This choice identifies a shape that is divided into 4 pieces but does not consider that the pieces are not all equal-sized.

SubTopics: Tell, show, and/or write time (analog) to the nearest minute.
Calculate elapsed time to the minute in a given situation (total elapsed time limited to 60 minutes or less).
Content: Jill worked on her homework for 23 minutes.
She had to stop at 6:00 for dinner.
Which clock shows the time Jill began her homework?

Key.Rationale: This choice recognizes that the time is before 6:00, so selects an hour hand pointing between the 5 and 6, but selects a minute hand pointing to 23 minutes after the hour rather than 23 minutes before the hour.

This choice recognizes that the clock should show 23 minutes before 6:00, so selects an hour (shorter) hand pointing between the 5 and 6 and a minute (longer) hand pointing at the third tick mark before the 8 since this represents 23 minutes before the hour.
This choice selects a clock showing 23 minutes after 6:00 rather than 23 minutes before 6:00.
This choice selects a minute hand pointing to 23 minutes before the hour but selects an hour hand pointing to a time after 6:00 (between the 6 and 7) rather than before 6:00 (between the 5 and 6).

SubTopics: Compare total values of combinations of coins (penny, nickel, dime, and quarter) and/or dollar bills less than $5.00.
Content: Kendra has $2.31, and Logan has $2.76.
Bella has more money than Kendra, but she has less money than Logan.
Which amount of money could be the money Bella has?

Key.Rationale: This choice either selects the amount of money Kendra has OR confuses the values of nickels and dimes, for a total of $2.46.
This choice counts each quarter as 5 cents, for a total of $2.35.
This choice determines that the value of the coins is 57 cents, which is between 31 cents and 76 cents, but does not consider that there is only one $1 bill.
This choice calculates $1 bill = $1.00, 5 quarters = $1.25, 2 dimes = $0.20, 3 nickels = $0.15, and 1 penny = $0.01 for a total of $2.61, which is more than $2.31 and less than $2.76.

SubTopics: Generate measurement data by measuring lengths using rulers marked with halves and fourths of an inch. Display the data by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked in appropriate units â€” whole numbers, halves, or quarters.
Content: Mr. Arden grew some green beans as shown below.
problems/PA23G3M/media/14a.jpg
Use your ruler to measure the lengths, to the nearest quarter inch, of the green beans.
Which line plot represents the lengths, to the nearest quarter inch, of the green beans?

Key.Rationale: This choice uses only 1 mark for each length.

This choice determines that the length of each of the three smaller beans is 1 3/4 inches long and each of the two longer beans is 2 1/2 inches long; on the line plot, indicates these measurements by using three marks at 1 3/4 and two marks at 2 2/4, since 2/4 is equivalent to 1/2.
This choice measures the beans to the nearest half inch, rounding each of the smaller measurements up to 2 inches, and uses only 1 mark for each length.
This choice measures the beans to the nearest half inch, rounding each of the smaller measurements up to 2 inches.

SubTopics: Measure areas by counting unit squares (square cm, square m, square in., square ft, and non-standard square units).
Content: Mr. Gomez uses square tiles to cover the kitchen floor as shown below.
problems/PA23G3M/media/15a.jpg
Each square tile has an area of one square foot.
What is the area, in square feet, of the kitchen floor?

Key.Rationale: This choice counts only the tiles along the outer edge of the figure.
This choice determines the perimeter of the figure.
This choice counts all the tiles to get 30 total (may use various grouping strategies so as not to count the tiles one at a time).
This choice multiplies the overall length (8) by the overall width (5).

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side lengths, finding an unknown side length, exhibiting rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas, and exhibiting rectangles with the same area and different perimeters. Use the same units throughout the problem.
Content: William makes the sign shown.
problems/PA23G3M/media/16a.jpg
What is the perimeter, in inches, of William's sign?

Key.Rationale: This choice omits one of the 10-inch sides.
This choice omits one of the 6-inch sides.
This choice adds the lengths of all five sides and determines the sum is 40.
This choice uses 10 inches for the 8-inch side.

SubTopics: Apply place-value strategies to solve problems.
Use operations, patterns, and estimation strategies to solve problems (may include word problems).
Content: Elyssa, Kendra, Hendrix, and Mike played a game.

:ibox:â€¢ Elyssa scored 132 points.

â€¢ Kendra scored 97 points.

â€¢ Hendrix scored 105 points.

â€¢ Mike scored 68 points.
What is the difference between the number of points Elyssa scored and the number of points Kendra scored?
Write a number sentence using <, >, or = to compare the number of points Elyssa scored to the number of points Kendra scored.
List the four scores in order from the ð—šð—¥ð—˜ð—”ð—§ð—˜ð—¦ð—§ number of points to the ð—Ÿð—˜ð—”ð—¦ð—§ number of points.
Explain how you used place value to determine which score is the ð—šð—¥ð—˜ð—”ð—§ð—˜ð—¦ð—§.
